Unfortunately, 1.0.0 won't work.  We'll have to keep the dependency on 1.0.0-pre3 for now.  We'll work on making our 1.1.0 release compatible with Beam.  I should also raise a bug with the protobuf team.

FWIW, we are actively working on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2955 / "Create a Cloud Bigtable HBase connector".  The new HBase connector will be able to use the shaded client to skirt around these issues.

@iemejia validates runner tests fail with unrelated issue: failure is in `ResumeFromCheckpointStreamingTest` on `java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/kafka/common/protocol/SecurityProtocol`
For the failure on regular build, it is not related to this PR either: failure is in `org.apache.beam.examples.WordCountIT.testE2EWordCount` on spark `org.apache.beam.sdk.Pipeline$PipelineExecutionException: java.io.IOException: Connection from /127.0.0.1:43119 closed`

@echauchot, I'll answer and comment here since previous PR was closed.

> is there any embedded version of kinesis provided by Amazon for the tests?

Unfortunately, no. Only third-party implementation, for example [https://github.com/localstack/localstack](url) and [https://github.com/mhart/kinesalite](url)

> yes too early is what I meant, there is nothing related to backend resilience. I've seen cases (see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2541) where users create the graph on their dev machines that do not have access to the backend and then deploy and run pipeline in dataflow. expand() is invoked at construction time, you need to do the check at runtime. I had this discussion with @jkff as well on ES5 PR

I've got your point and agree with it. So yes, it makes sense to move this check into `@setup`.

> this KinesisRecordToTestData class is both in kinesis write test and in kinessis read test

Yes, I'll fix this. Good catch, thanx!

I had a (hopefully) clever idea to have different versions of the proto and bigtable-client jars.  I kept the client at 1.0.0 and reverted the proto jar to 1.0.0-pre3.  That should hopefully fix the problem.

Ok after some research you are right, when you define the versions in <pluginManagement> they are correctly inherited save for the use of plugins in profiles, in that case you have to be put versions explicitly.

We have some plugins that weren't correctly defined in <pluginManagement> so I moved them and the inheritance works now. Only exception is surefire tha tis used in profiles so I had to put the explicit version there.

I am pushing the updated changes and also some extra improvements to remove other annoying warnings that have been introduced recently.

@kennknowles PTAL

It seems good in general that TestPipeline tests that the serialization of pipeline options works. In particular, this may be needed if we want to pass options through the Runner API to the actual runner.

R: @aaltay (please merge) 
(It should work this time! Thank you!)
@echauchot I fixed two issues that you requested. Please, take a look on this https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4468/commits/80549d754c85b93c84c09280b37ff3ed1689fdd9
Line lengths fixed, which is all I could see being problematic.
Ok, then we need a way for tests to bypass this so specified options aren't dropped.

In the portable future, options are allowed/expected to be serialized on their way to a runner. So that means `@JsonIgnore` options are just a way to use `PipelineOptions` for Beam-irrelevant command line parsing. We shouldn't really encourage that, since mature/stanardized command line libraries are more appropriate.
@kennknowles Ah, ok. Thank you for the explanation!

Serialization of pipeline options should only matter between SDK and runner like Kenn says and not between test infrastructure and SDK.

I'm all for having a good way to do args parsing and dependency passing outside of PipelineOptions, I just don't see that being feasible while being backwards compatible. Also using two argument parsing systems is typically awkward so I can't see a migration away from using PipelineOptions, only a full swap to something else.

What I mean is that just using `PipelineOptions` to configure a user's `main()` program is not great.

The `PipelineOptions` absolutely should go through a serialization round trip before they reach the runner, since this is to spec. We should fix anything that breaks because of it.

@pgerv12 can you describe the particular problem that happened? I do think that existing runners may have a lot of dependencies on non-serializable options just for configuration. But for a non-Java SDKs the options _have_ to come serialized, so we need to fix the runners to have all of their configuration specified in ways that can be sent that way.

This is really cool! Thank you. Is it possible to try this job before merging? (Maybe by running the seed job first?)

cc: @herohde @kennknowles

I see. This makes a lot of sense, and should be supported until we have a complete portability story.

For reference, in the portable model the Java SDK harness will execute the user's UDFs, so it would own options like this. Artifact staging goes over the "Artifact API" (just a proxy for staging via a runner-specific mechanism) and the Java construction side and Java execution side use it however they want, and just have to agree. So then `@JsonIgnore` is fine for files to stage again.

For your case, now, can you just make the option not `@JsonIgnore`? If that is a problem, them I'm OK with this change but we should develop a proper plan for `TestPipeline` to function appropriately for both styles of runner.
This should be ready to review
Yes, our workaround it to remove the annotations and things work well with the change. I'm glad we're having this discussion because I didn't know what the proper behavior should be.

`jarsToStage` sounds a lot like `filesToStage`. Note that `filesToStage` is not marked with `@JsonIgnore` for Flink/Spark/Dataflow.

Dropping the `@JsonIgnore` seems like the right approach but also consider migrating to use `filesToStage` and the same jar detection code which Flink/Spark/Dataflow all share as can be seen here: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/9ad40dc9e1cab588bd44a5b0f98995b9226707b6/runners/flink/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/flink/FlinkRunner.java#L76

Note that the sdks/java/container module has a dependency on go code, but it doesn't look like a maven dependency. Note that this will be brittle in the long run as more cross language dependencies develop and our migration to Gradle will make this moot.

I'll merge since this genuinely may help some developers, otherwise please close this PR.

> Often working on a feature or even more on a fix you only care about a language - which is probably most of the time java?

You mean probably most of the time Python, right :)?

Ideally this could be deduced via dependencies, e.g. we should be able to say "test everything that depends on anything that's changed (according to git?).

There seem to be some workers that don't have Maven 3.5.2 installed, see:
https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/17030/console

While others do have Maven 3.5.2 and are able to build successfully.

The `ZERO` distribution result was created so it would be an identity element, meaning that it should hold that `ZERO.combine(SomeResult) == SomeResult`. The MIN / MAX elements of that zero are MAX_INT and MIN_INT respectively, so that this property would hold.
Migrated away from using the supplier of partial state requests to using explicit parameters.
